title: Marla Maples - Wikipedia
author: Authority control International FAST VIAF National United States Poland Artists MusicBrainz
cleaned_text: Maples (born October 27, 1963) [[1]](#cite_note-:1-1) is an American actress, television personality, model, singer and presenter. She was the second wife of [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump). They married in 1993, two months after the birth of their daughter [Tiffany](/wiki/Tiffany_Trump), and divorced in 1999. [[2]](#cite_note-2) [[3]](#cite_note-3) Early life[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Marla_Maples&action=edit§ion=1)] Maples was born on October 1963, in [Cohutta, Georgia](/wiki/Cohutta,_Georgia). Her mother, Ann Locklear Maples, was a homemaker and model, and her father, Stanley Edward Maples, a real estate developer, county commissioner, singer, and songwriter. [[4]](#cite_note-heart-4) [[5]](#cite_note-5) [[6]](#cite_note-6) Maples attended [Northwest Whitfield High School](/wiki/Northwest_Whitfield_High_School) in [Tunnel Hill, Georgia](/wiki/Tunnel_Hill,_Georgia), where she played basketball, served as class secretary and was crowned the 1980-1981 [homecoming queen](/wiki/Homecoming_queen) during her senior year (she returned for the 1991 homecoming to crown the school's new queen). [[7]](#cite_note-7) After graduating from high school in 1981, Maples competed in beauty contests and pageants. In 1983, she won the Miss Resaca Beach Poster Girl Contest, in 1984 she was the runner-up to [Miss Georgia USA](/wiki/Miss_Georgia_USA), and in 1985 she won the [Miss Hawaiian Tropic](/wiki/Miss_Hawaiian_Tropic). [[8]](#cite_note-8) [[9]](#cite_note-9) She entered the [University of Georgia](/wiki/University_of_Georgia) in 1981 but left college before graduating. [[4]](#cite_note-heart-4) Career[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Marla_Maples&action=edit§ion=2)] Film, television, and theater[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Marla_Maples&action=edit§ion=3)] In 1991, appeared as a celebrity guest at [WWF](/wiki/WWE) [WrestleMania VII](/wiki/WrestleMania_VII), serving as special guest timekeeper in the main event match between [Hulk Hogan](/wiki/Hulk_Hogan) and defending WWF Champion [Sgt. Slaughter](/wiki/Sgt._Slaughter). In that year, Maples also made a special appearance in the hit television series [Designing Women](/wiki/Designing_Women) as herself. In August 1992, Maples joined the cast of the [Tony Award](/wiki/Tony_Award) winning Broadway musical [The Will Rogers Follies](/wiki/The_Will_Rogers_Follies) as " [Ziegfeld](/wiki/Ziegfeld)'s Favorite", a role originated by [Cady Huffman](/wiki/Cady_Huffman) when the show opened in May 1991. [[10]](#cite_note-10) [[11]](#cite_note-11) In 1994, Maples appeared alongside then-husband [Donald a [cameo appearance](/wiki/Cameo_appearance) an episode of [The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air](/wiki/The_Fresh_Prince_of_Bel-Air) [[12]](#cite_note-12) and the television series [Something Wilder](/wiki/Something_Wilder) in 1994. Maples co-hosted the 1996 and 1997 [Miss Universe Pageant](/wiki/Miss_Universe_Pageant) and the 1997 [Miss USA Pageant](/wiki/Miss_USA_Pageant), both of which were owned by her then-husband. [[13]](#cite_note-13) Maples appeared in the films [Two of Hearts](/wiki/Two_of_Hearts_(film)) (1999), Loving Annabelle (2006), A Christmas Too Many (2007), and [A Nanny for Christmas](/wiki/A_Nanny_for_Christmas) (2010).[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] In 2011, she returned to New York for [Love, Loss and What I Wore](/wiki/Love,_Loss_and_What_I_Wore), an off-Broadway production. [[14]](#cite_note-14) In 2013, Maples was featured on [Oprah: Where Are They Now?](/wiki/Oprah:_Where_Are_They_Now%3F) [[15]](#cite_note-15) Since then, she appeared in Switching Lanes, directed by [Thomas Mikal Ford](/wiki/Thomas_Mikal_Ford). [[16]](#cite_note-16) [[17]](#cite_note-17) On March 8, 2016, Maples was announced as one of the celebrities who would compete on [season 22](/wiki/Dancing_with_the_Stars_(U.S._season_22)) of [Dancing with the Stars](/wiki/Dancing_with_the_Stars_(U.S._TV_series)) alongside co-star, [Kim [[19]](#cite_note-19) Maples and Dovolani were eliminated on Week 4 of competition and finished in 10th place. Maples also joined the women of ABC's morning talk show, [The View](/wiki/The_View_(U.S._TV_series)), as a guest co-host on March 11, 2016. [[20]](#cite_note-20) Maples is a keynote speaker with the London Speakers Bureau, focusing on inspiring women, wellness, spirituality, and motivation. [[21]](#cite_note-21) Maples was featured in the Summer of Peace Summit 2018 with the opportunity to discuss topics of peace and finding common ground. [[22]](#cite_note-22) Maples spoke at the 2018 Global Summit on Science, Spirituality, and Environment in India; the event brought together speakers from around the world to discuss the integration of science and spirituality, as well as self-transformation and world-transformation. [[23]](#cite_note-23) Maples was a guest speaker on the Journeys of Faith podcast with [Paula Faris](/wiki/Paula_Faris) in 2018. [[24]](#cite_note-24) Radio and music[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Marla_Maples&action=edit§ion=4)] Maples hosted her own talk radio show, Awakening with Marla, on Contact Talk Radio. Her guests included [naturopathic](/wiki/Naturopathic) doctors, authors, and astrologers. [[25]](#cite_note-25) Maples' album The Endless, released in August 2013, is a musical journey of spiritual awakening and transformational energy, featuring thought leaders such as won a " [Hollywood Music in Media Award](/wiki/Hollywood_Music_in_Media_Award)" for best New Age/Ambient song, for "House of Love", that album. [[26]](#cite_note-iTunes-26) [[27]](#cite_note-27) Other[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Marla_Maples&action=edit§ion=5)] In 1990, Maples starred in an advertising campaign for No Excuses jeans. [[28]](#cite_note-28) In 1993, she designed a line of maternity clothes, sold in several major department stores. [[29]](#cite_note-29) In January 2000, a memoir by Maples, All That Glitters Is Not Gold, was announced by the [ReganBooks](/wiki/ReganBooks) division of [HarperCollins Publishers](/wiki/HarperCollins_Publishers). In February 2002, a spokeswoman for the publishing company said, "The author and publisher by mutual consent have agreed not to publish the book." [[30]](#cite_note-:0-30) Maples makes personalized videos through the website Cameo. [[31]](#cite_note-31) Philanthropy[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Marla_Maples&action=edit§ion=6)] Maples is committed to supporting charities and non-profit organizations and is a long-time vocal advocate of Kids Creating Peace, an organization uniting Israeli and Palestinian children. [[32]](#cite_note-32) Maples is involved with AWARENYC.org as an advisory board member. AWARE (Assisting Women through Action, Resources & Education) is a grassroots organization dedicated to promoting awareness and generating funds in order to make meaningful improvements in the lives of women and girls in the New York City community and worldwide. [[33]](#cite_note-33) Maples also supports and is on the Steering Committee for The Louis Armstrong Center for Music and Medicine. [[34]](#cite_note-34) Personal life[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Marla_Maples&action=edit§ion=7)] Relationships[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Marla_Maples&action=edit§ion=8)] Maples' relationship with [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump) was initiated while he was married to his first wife, [Ivana](/wiki/Ivana_Trump), whom Trump divorced in 1990. [[35]](#cite_note-35) Maples met him in 1984 and had a highly publicized relationship [[36]](#cite_note-36) later with at least one breakup. [[37]](#cite_note-carswell19910708-37) One [New York Post](/wiki/New_York_Post) headline reported that, according to Maples, she had the " [best sex I've ever had](/wiki/Best_Sex_I%27ve_Ever_Had)" with Trump. [[38]](#cite_note-sporkin19900305-38) [[39]](#cite_note-ah20110105-39) [[40]](#cite_note-farhi20161201-40) The couple had one daughter, [Tiffany Trump](/wiki/Tiffany_Trump), born on October 13, 1993. [[41]](#cite_note-:2-41) According to Maples, the [1993 Long Island Rail Road shooting](/wiki/1993_Long_Island_Rail_Road_shooting), on December 7, caused Trump to reevaluate his life and propose to her. [[42]](#cite_note-elison201702-42) The couple married on December 20, 1993, at New York City's [Plaza Hotel](/wiki/Plaza_Hotel), in a ceremony reportedly attended by 1,000 including [Rosie O'Donnell](/wiki/Rosie_O%27Donnell) and [O. J. Simpson](/wiki/O._J._Simpson). [[43]](#cite_note-43) [[44]](#cite_note-44) In 1996, Trump fired his bodyguard Spencer Wagner after a police officer found Maples and the bodyguard together under a lifeguard stand on a deserted beach at 4:00 a.m. [[45]](#cite_note-:3-45) Both Maples and Trump denied that she was having an affair, despite reports in the [National Enquirer](/wiki/National_Enquirer) and other tabloids; the bodyguard himself told conflicting stories about the incident. [[45]](#cite_note-:3-45) [[41]](#cite_note-:2-41) Maples and Trump separated in May 1997 [[46]](#cite_note-46) and divorced on June 8, 1999. [[30]](#cite_note-:0-30) Under the terms of their [prenuptial agreement](/wiki/Prenuptial_agreement) and divorce settlement, Maples is bound by a confidentiality agreement regarding their marriage. [[30]](#cite_note-:0-30) [[41]](#cite_note-:2-41) Health and wellness[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Marla_Maples&action=edit§ion=9)] Maples is an advocate of health and wellness. Her daughter Tiffany Trump has described Maples making her healthy homemade chocolate in [Trump Tower](/wiki/Trump_Tower); meanwhile her father would sneak her downstairs to the candy store to buy her [Almond Joys](/wiki/Almond_Joy). [[47]](#cite_note-47) Maples describes herself as a "mostly- [vegan](/wiki/Veganism)" who avoids dairy, eats organic, and chooses to [gluten free](/wiki/Gluten-free_diet). [[48]](#cite_note-48) [[49]](#cite_note-49) During the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019), Maples used her social media platforms to promote treatments that have not been proven effective, such as [vitamin C drips](/wiki/Intravenous_ascorbic_acid). She also joined [Children's Health Defense](/wiki/Children%27s_Health_Defense)'s [Robert F. Kennedy Jr.](/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr.) in touting 'Dancing With the Stars' | Radio and TV Talk"](https://web.archive.org/web/20180325123044/http://radiotvtalk.blog.ajc.com/2016/03/06/donald-trump-ex-georgia-native-marla-maples-on-dancing-with-the-stars/).
